facts.text: The respondent joined the service of the appellant-bank on June 14, 1951 and after confirmation in September 1952 was posted at Udipi.
The respondent was later transferred to Trichur but on his representation was transferred to Mandvi Branch, Bombay, in July 1956.
On May 20, 1961, another order of transfer was made by the appellant-bank posting the respondent back at Trichur.
The present application under S. 33A was made on August 26, 1961, praying that the transfer order of May 20, 1961 be cancelled and the respondent permitted to continue at Bombay.

It was alleged in the application that the appellant made the transfer order mala fide and as an act of victimization for the lawful trade union activities of the complainant. It was also alleged that the transfer was made to deprive the complainant of his lawful dues.

This application was made before the National Industrial Tribunal at Bombay before which proceedings in respect of an industrial dispute between the appellant-bank and its workmen was then pending. The National Tribunal transferred the application to the Labour Court, Ahmedabad, for disposal.

Before the Labour Court the appellant contended that there had been no contravention of the provisions of s. 33 of the Industrial Disputes Act as no change had been made in the service conditions of the respondents employment and further that the transfer had been made bona fide on account of sheer business considerations and exigencies of business.
It was also contended that the order of transfer made by the bank did not offend the terms of the Sastry Award on the question of transfer of Bank employees.

The Labour Court held that under the terms of the Sastry Award the appellants right to transfer his employees was limited to this extent that a clerk like the respondent could not be transferred outside the State or language area in which he had been serving except with his consent.

Holding that there had been no such consent, it came to the conclusion that the conditions of service of the respondent had been altered in a manner not in accordance with the standing order contained in the Sastry Award.
The Court rejected the allegation that the transfer had been made to victimize the respondent for his union activities.

Being of opinion however that by the transfer the appellant had materially altered the respondents service conditions and this alteration was not in accordance with Sastry Award, the Court directed the bank to cancel the transfer order and to retransfer the complainant to Mandvi Branch, Bombay.

It is not disputed that these directions were binding on the appellant-bank nor is it disputed before us that these directions amounted to standing orders applicable to Banks workmen within the meaning of s. 33(2) of the Industrial Disputes Act.
It cannot also be doubted that the result of the transfer would be a material alteration in the respondents conditions of service.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Labour Court erred in holding that the direction in the Sastry Award absolutely prohibited the Bank from transferring workmen not belonging to the subordinate staff outside the State or the language area in which the employee had been serving except with his consent.

Whether the bank contravened the direction in the Sastry Award by transferring the respondent outside the Maharashtra State and language area, given that the transfer was made bona fide in the interests of business.

petitioner_arguments.text: The Labour Court erred in thinking that the direction in the Sastry Award absolutely prohibited the Bank from transferring workmen not belonging to the subordinate staff outside the State or the language area except with consent. On a proper construction, it only required the bank to refrain from making such transfers as far as possible and did not prevent the bank from making such transfers where it was really found necessary in banks interests.

When the bank claimed to have made the transfer in the interests of its business and was found to have acted bona fide, it should have been held that the direction in the Sastry Award had not been contravened.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Sastry Award; s. 33 Industrial Disputes Act

respondent_arguments.text: The appellant made the transfer order mala fide and as an act of victimization for the lawful trade union activities of the complainant. The transfer was made to deprive the complainant of his lawful dues.

court_reasoning.text: The Sastry Award drew a distinction between subordinate staff (absolute prohibition beyond language area) and others (as far as possible no transfer outside State or language area without consent). The words 'as far as possible' were deliberately used to leave it to the banks to decide on consideration of necessities of business interests whether such transfer could be avoided.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Labour Court erred in holding transfers outside State/language area can only be made with consent; such transfers can be made if unavoidable for business.

court_reasoning.text: Management of the bank is in the best position to judge distribution of manpower; ordinarily accept management's submission that transfer unavoidable unless mala fide or victimization.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Labour Court rejected mala fides; no evidence of victimization; thus transfer in accordance with Sastry Award.

court_reasoning.text: The Labour Court was not justified in thinking that the respondents transfer to Trichur could have been avoided without injury to banks interests.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Transfer works harshly on employee but does not amount to unfair labour practice.

holdings.text: Sastry Award permits transfer of non-subordinate staff outside State/language area where necessary for bank interests, to be avoided as far as possible; management decides bona fides.
No contravention of Sastry Award where transfer bona fide and unavoidable for business, absent mala fides.

statutes_cited.name: Industrial Disputes Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Application under s.33A for alleged contravention of s.33 during pendency of dispute; Sastry Award as standing orders under s.33(2)

outcome.summary: The appeal is allowed, the order of the Labour Court is set aside and it is ordered that the respondents application under s.33A be rejected.
outcome.relief_granted: Cancellation of Labour Court direction to cancel transfer order

key_quotes.text: "We direct that in general the policy should be to limit the transfers to minimum consistent with the banking needs and efficiency. So far as members of the subordinate establishment are concerned there should be no transfers ordinarily and if there are any transfers at all, they should not be beyond the language area of the person so transferred."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Relevant direction from Sastry Award on transfers for subordinate staff

key_quotes.text: "We further direct that even in the case of workmen not belonging to the subordinate staff, as far as possible there should be no transfer outside the State or the language areas in which the employee has been serving except, of course, with his consent."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key clause interpreted by Supreme Court as not absolute prohibition

key_quotes.text: "It is not possible for industrial tribunals to have before them all the materials which are relevant for this purpose and even if these could be made available the tribunals are by no means suited for making decisions in matters of this nature."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Justifies deference to management's judgment on transfers
